DataElement.preferredName: Dynamic Susceptibility Contrast Magnetic Resonance Relative Regional Cerebral Blood Volume Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Value for the measure of regional blood supply in a cerebrovascular area using Dynamic Susceptibility Contrast (DSC) imaging methods. [Manually-curated]

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Dynamic Susceptibility Contrast Magnetic Resonance Relative Regional Cerebral Blood Volume
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The constitutional or inborn state disposing to a disease, group of diseases, or metabolic or structural anomaly._The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object._Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders._(seh-REE-bral HEM-iss-feer) One half of the cerebrum, the part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body, and the left hemisphere controls the muscles on the right side of the body._The sum of a set of values divided by the number of values in the set._Substances administered during diagnostic procedures that allows delineation of internal structures.  Contrast agents appear opaque due to the difference in absorption of X-rays or other electromagnetic waves and surrounding tissue._the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past._Considered in comparison with something else; dependent on or interconnected with something else; not absolute._A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood._Volume; the amount of 3-dimensional space occupied by an object.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The constitutional or inborn state disposing to a disease, group of diseases, or metabolic or structural anomaly.:The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.:Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: The constitutional or inborn state disposing to a disease, group of diseases, or metabolic or structural anomaly.
The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Property.preferredName: Relative Value Regional Cerebral Hemisphere Blood Volume
Property.preferredDefinition: Considered in comparison with something else; dependent on or interconnected with something else; not absolute.:Regional; limited to a particular location or area.:(seh-REE-bral HEM-iss-feer) One half of the cerebrum, the part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body,:Blood circulating throughout the body.:Volume; the amount of 3-dimensional space occupied by an object.

Concepts.definition: Considered in comparison with something else; dependent on or interconnected with something else; not absolute.
Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body.

The part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body, and the left hemisphere controls the muscles on the right side of the body.

A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Regional; limited to a particular location or area.:Blood circulating throughout the body.:Volume; the amount of 3-dimensional space occupied by an object.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body.

A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support MGH adoption of C3D
